description.text:
It's a horned helmet I designed in moi3d. It's hollow on the inside.
On a side note: apparently vikings didn't put horns on their helmets.

Printed just fine with standard settings in about an hour on my makerbot.
The second file is higher resolution.

Picatinny mount with a diameter of 25 mm for mounting a scope, bullet camera or (infrared)light source to a gun. The mount is slightly smaller then the rail and a 1 inch scope. You have to sand it to allow for a tight fit and cut the mounting ring parallel to the barrel to insert a scope or other object. There are 2 holes either for 2 2mm screws or a cable strip to fasten the mount to the rail and the scope or camera. Warning: Mounting a light source to a gun is illegal many european countries and especially Germany. In Germany the mounting bracket is allowed though, because it can be used for a scope or a dummy ( at example when you glue a plastic cylinder like an old uhu stick into the mounting bracket like on the last image). If you want to use the mount for movies or in collecting guns and mount a light to it you have to fill the light it with epoxy or something if you want to do it legally in Germany. The gun depicted is an airsoft gun. Edit: erroneous .stl replaced
Edit: included netfab version

comments.text: What purpose does a glue stick do on a gun?

description.text:
Update 21/2/18: Final release version of the enclosure module. Please delete all previous versions.

Parametric enclosure with customisable front/rear rounding and top/bottom fillets. Faster and more predictable than a Minkowski method, this module should cause minimal issues when used in complex designs.

Non-commercial derivatives are allowed as long as they comply with the included licence.

title: 10 Gallon Fish Tank Cover Hinge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This particular part broke on my 10 Gallon Fish Tank that I bought at Walmart years ago. It connects the top hood to the tank. My 3D Printer and Sketchup came to the rescue! This is the real value and purpose of 3D printers, creating parts that would be nearly impossible to find or buy.

This was my first 3D printer creation. I was really proud of it. Sketchup made designing the part much easier.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Since I was new to printing, I used 50% infill to ensure that part would be strong. It hasn't failed me yet after close to a year.

description.text: On reddit, there have been multiple cube stands that are designed just like this one. I decided to make one for 3D printing and made this in TinkerCad quickly. Hope you guys enjoy!

This is a little desktop PR display I designed for my desk for my PR's. It only goes to a half marathon right now since I'm a looong way from doing a full and I wanted it as compact as possible. There's no oddball race lengths but in my area we have a lot of the ones listed with the 15K being a fairly big but unique race famous in the region.

To use you'll need the display, two of the feet and four of the display plaques. The display plaque are set up to hold a small piece of paper that you'd print or write your current PR's on.

I was printing 3D text hangers for my PR's but I wanted something more useful for folks that don't own a 3D printer with the people I run with so something they could change on their own made more sense.

Everything should print without supports or rafts on most printers. There are a few sloped overhangs but the slope is such they should be fine.

description.text:
This is a funnel for the portafilter that comes with the Mr. Coffee brand espresso machine shown in the included pictures (they have changed the design several times over the years, so make sure you have the same model). Just drop it in and pour your grounds without making a mess! Works well with my tamping station (as shown in the pic) that can be found here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1975420

Some thoughts on food safety:

This item will come in contact with coffee grounds, so please do treat in a food-safe-ish manner before use. I print in ABS and brushing with acetone yields a smoother, less porous, and hopefully food-safer surface. A couple of coats of food-safe polyurethane is another technique I have heard about. It might be worth looking into different options, but the risk here is minimal because we are dealing with dry food and very brief contact.

Printer:

Qidi Tech I

Rafts:

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I have modded my Qidi Tech I to use a glass print bed, and I did not have any adhesion issues printing narrow side down without a raft. If you have trouble with print bed adhesion, a raft might be useful. Supports are not required.

This is a stand for the Ticwatch 2 smart watch. It uses the orignal wireless charger and usb cable and is no wider than the watch straps. Whether crown down or up, the watch will stay supported.

Use double-sided tape to mount the wirless charger to the dock.

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

70%+

Notes:

Prints well on printers with great cooling that is directed at the print as this has unsupported gaps and steep angles.

Mounting the Charger
  1. Clean any strings
  2. Apply double-sided tape to the back tab
  3. Take the original or a USB cable and feed it through the hole behind the watch supports.
  4. Connect the cable to the charger unit
  5. Slide the cable and charger flush agaist the tape and walls

Recommended to apply double-sided tape to the bottom of the dock when placing it on a table to prevent it from sliding.

description.text:
Here's my latest revision of a mount for the Access Port V3 - with the standard mount it comes with. I found double sided tape wasn't working very well, and nothing would stick to the bezel of the stack.

What you'll need:
M3 Bolt: 10 - 15mm long should be fine
M3 nut

Peel the double sided tape off the original mount, and it should slide into the slot (tip, if you're having difficulty sliding the original mount into the 3D printed mount, use a lighter to slightly heat the slot, then slide the original mount into the slot. Slide the bolt through the hole, put the nut on, then screw the bolt into the stub. There is also a small bit of support included in the design, it's pretty obvious what you need to clip off after printing.

After 6 revisions, the Solidworks file is a bit messy, but feel free to edit it if you'd like. I may do a rev. 7 when I print the ABS version for summer. Comment/PM me if you're interested in making changes or have suggestions!

I used a small bit of cork between the stopper and the stack bezel just to give it some extra grip and prevent any scratches.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.3

Infill:

40+

Notes:

Recommend ABS as PLA deforms in warm cars during summer. High infill for additional strength, however 20% worked fine for my prototyping.
Remove small bit of support included in design file.

description.text: I finished my printer and am posting all the bits and pieces that are needed to complete the assembly. If you build a HyperCube printer, you will probably want a switch and fuse for the power inlet. This panel mounts on to the 2020 extrusion and accepts one of the standard power inlet modules. The 10A fuse gives you some safety and the switch to power the printer off provides convenience. The cord is also removable. It takes four 5 mm X 10 mm button head screws and extrusion fasteners to mount this panel.

define Z_ENDSTOP_SERVO_NR 1

define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 43 // Y offset: -front + behind [the nozzle]

This is a customizable USB key case.

Shapes that can be produced include: triangles, squares, pentagram, hexagon, heptagon, octagon or as many facets that you want to include. You can also add a twist to the USB case shape using the twist variable.

Measure the dimensions of the circuit portion of the USB and well as the dimensions of the metal portion that connects to your computer. It seems there are some variations between the sizes of the circuit portion of the USB keys that I have.

Secure the USB into the case using your glue of choice. The cap of the USB case has been designed for cube magnets to keep the cap in place. Use glue to secure the magnet into the case cap.

title: Mini Monster Truck/Car/Smart With Suspension - REMIX

description.text:
I remixed jakejake's Mini Monster Truck With Suspension. I like the idea of the printed suspension, but I wanted more options for the Monster Truck body. I have had success with designing and printing tongue and groove assemblies, so I combined that with jakejake's truck.

I made several option bodies and included a blank template for those who want to design their own. I imported jakejake's truck body into Solid Works and cut off the top and added the tongue. The MonsterTruck and MonsterStealth bodies were my design and drawn in Solid Works. My first design was the smart, but I used an image in Inkscape and exported the dxf, so not really my design. The blank has the groove stop set at the right distance to the lines that mark the axle distance. I made plain versions of the Smart and Truck, but I like the swoop lines on the originals.

This design reduces the need for support. I printed the support version of the body, but all the tops can be printed without any support.

The tongue and grooves have 0.2mm clearance. They fit tightly, but if the edges are sanded, they should slide fairly smoothly.

Happy printing!

Da Vinci 1.0

No

title: Anet A6 Power Supply Cover and Switch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This cover and bracket is for a Newstyle 360W power supply or similar. I wanted a beefier power supply to improve bed and nozzle warm up times. This is perfect for that.

The bracket converts from the original screw layout to the new screw layout. To install the bracket, first you will need to place four M3 washers in the location of the old screws. I secured them with a small piece of tape so they didn't fall out. I then screwed the Power Supply bracket to the new power supply using 4 x M4(5MM) screws. I finally secured the power supply to the printer using 3 x M3(10MM) screws. The unused remaining screw/nut can be used in the future to mount something else to the power supply.

The power supply cover is then secured using 2 x M3(short screws) on the right side and a countersinking/fluted M3(short screw) on the left side. I secured the power switch using 2 x M4 (5MM) screws and nuts. The hole in the front of the cover is to allow for the adjustment of the power potentiometer.

With all Anet A6/A8 printers, A power supply cover is a "MUST HAVE" for the safety of children and pets. Please seriously consider it if you don't already have a cover. There are covers on Thingiverse for the original Anet A6 power supply.

Note: The pictures of my power supply cover above are for my previous version before I added the power supply bracket. The STL file provided is for the new power supply cover taking into account the power supply bracket. I haven't tested it for fit and would appreciate any feedback to make adjustments where necessary. Maybe one day, I'll print a new cover for myself.

Parts needed for this make:

Power Switch:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00F4MFMXE/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=10618a-20&camp=1789&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=B00F4MFMXE&linkId=1ada6a3c70766d697b162e2baaf10abe

Power Supply:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MAC9MO6/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=10618a-20&camp=1789&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=B00MAC9MO6&linkId=6063053ae818e7a7bc374d4166e3b9c5

Miscellaneous M3 and M4 screws and nuts as listed above:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01N3YDD01/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=10618a-20&camp=1789&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=B01N3YDD01&linkId=1afa81f3e64f533b5168353f3fbfe13f

title: Rock Paper Scissors Lizard Spock Cube

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cSLeBKT7-sM

Didn't like the final prints from first design so I completely redesigned it. My supports interfered with the detail too much for bottom part of cube. I redesigned it to have the holes so you can now just pop the discs in place. This also allows you to print different colors for each item if you desire. These prints came out MUCH better than the original design so please, if you are printing this, redownload!

Yes you read that correctly. A Rock, Paper, Scissors, Lizard, Spock cube to settle those pesky
arguments. No more feeling like you didn't get a fair shake. Print 2 or more of these and solve all of
your problems with a role of the cube!

This is a remix of the 20 sided cube referenced so there are 4 of each choices.

I will be making a cheat sheet tag for those that don't know that lizard poisons Spock and that
scissors decapitate lizard.

Have fun

Printer:

Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed all the discs at 100% infill, they are small enough to where it really doesn't matter.

I printed the cubes with a 40% infill for best results due to supports needed at bottom. I actually had some really decent prints with my rather low quality printer by making my support angle 85% so it just did a support for bottom hole. If you do use supports with an angle closer to 50^, than I would make your infill % 15% and play wit your xy, and z distances for infill to make sure the print is as smooth as possible.

The discs will fit right in place, a little glue to hold them is needed that way you don't have to jam them in.

description.text: I needed a replacement belt tensioner but found none that where completely printable, they all required other hardware. However, using the technique in this original part I was able to. The belt folds over itself and into its own teeth, so you can feed both sides of a cut belt in and just pull it to whatever tightness you need, slotting it in to the available tooth. The print is super simple too, without a real tensioner you can see the quality due to the slack, but it still printed very usable.

title: Compact Bowden Extruder for MK7 Drive Gear (1.75mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
All Original credit goes to tech2c. Heres why i did this. I was slightly under extruding. Different filaments gave me different results when calibrating my E steps. So,i noticed that the gap between the mk7 drive gear and the mount was large. So upon reading more into it, it should be smaller. Also this would also help when using flexible materials. So i decided to extend the mount closer to the drive gear.
Now my extrusion is perfect. I suspect the filament bent some previously.
**This was my case and may not be yours. Just sharing for others that may need it. For more info, go to the original thing.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jAogq9V8VMV

title: 1200 x 1200 Large scale DIY 3D printer - Sub33D v3.07

description.text:
Please check out the Build progress and test print preview video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eUf5-UCVueU

There is a playlist of full build progress updates and test print videos:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLW8e88EbKrS-baD0ZTySmq4-q1nxtejUq

800mm Ledgend of Zelda Master Sword test print:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNQMUBLKr4Y

T-Rex skull test print:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X6_i6DHRLhA

You can also check us out on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/Sub33D/

Filament for the printer is created on our own modified Lyman / Mulier version 5 Filament Extruder:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RwAdB6rVrKg

This printer was designed to print very large scale using recycled ABS plastic (we also recycle, shred and produce recycled ABS filament).
Most of the other very large scale printers out there tend to print in PLA which is a lot less problematic at large scale.

Main features:

  • Build volume 1200mm x 1200mm x 600mm
  • H bot layout with fixed heat-bed (4 x z-axis motors to move the light weight H frame rather than the insanely heavy heat-bed)
  • 1mm nozzle, double volcano extruder hot end to increase flow rate (80W total heater power)
  • 2400W heatbed using 4 x 230V 600W 400mm x 400mm silicone heating pads (controlled with 25A solid state relay)
  • 2 x Recycled Nema23 stepper motors for y-axis, driven by single 5A TB600 CNC type stepper driver
  • 4 x Recycled Nema23 stepper motors for z-axis, driven by single 5A TB600 CNC type stepper driver
  • 1 x Recycled Nema23 stepper motor for x-axis, driven by standard DRV8825 2.5A stepper driver
  • 1 x Recycled Nema17 stepper motor for extruder, driven by standard DRV8825 2.5A stepper driver
  • Modified Ultimaker 1.5.7 PCB main board
  • 4 x 150W IR heaters to reduce heat-bed deformation and maintain consistent heat on printed ABS parts.
  • Designed in Sketchup Make 2017, design file included in downloads (Sub33D v3.07.09.skp)
  • Frame built from 50mm x 50mm x 2mm box section aluminium
  • Total build cost is close to $2000 AUD, aproximately add another $500 AUD if your not using recycled components.﻿
  • Marlin-RC firmware also included in downloads (Marlin-RC.zip)

If anyone is thinking to build something like this I would recommend using a 12mm heat-bed plate (rather than 6mm) as the aluminium plate deforms up to 5mm when heated to 90 deg C, I am using 9 x 9 point auto-bed leveling to pick up the deformation shape).
Also the 400mm x 400m 600W silicone heaters are a little small as the distance between them causes around a 10 deg C difference on the heat-bed surface between the heaters and above them).

I'm Currently building a new dual 100mm stack extruder with 8 x 40W heater cartridges to allow for a 4 x increase in flow rate over the current design, as the printing speed at this volume is way to slow, once this is done I will share some more of the design details.

Special thanks to Substation33 for all the support and recycled materials.

comments.text: Since the bed is stationary, would you think it possible to use a different heat source like Warm up brand heated flooring? You can make it exactly the size you want. Take durock, thinset and screw to wood plywood. Run the warmup wire on top of that, don't forget to add and check heat sensor before going any further. Make a frame around this as a box 1" higher than the wire, mix and pack mud (1:3 ratio of portland cement to course sand) use very little water. You want the mud stronger than usual. Take some mud squeeze it, should stay together than bounce it off hand if it breaks in large chunks than it good. Take stick wider than box and run across to make perfectly flat. Let dry, than take kerabond and glue metal to the dimentions of wood frame to lock everything in place. Slip your machine over this square. I use metal bed with kapton tape and hairspray (aqua net). With the bed pre heated I spray it and then hit print. By the time the extruder heats up the hairspray is just the right tackiness. When the print is done you smack it with a scraper handle and it pops off.  After the bed is half cooled down of course. This trick I haven't had ripped kapton, I've been using the same tape for over a year. Wipe the bed with a wet towel after a couple times cause you get build up. I hope this helps with your machine. This way should give you the most even distribution of controlled heat. You could even take and enclose the whole thing in plexiglass as well, drafts and people walking by can mess a print up as well.

description.text:
This is a Watch stand.
Recently, I bought a watch. Therefore, I made a stand for a watch.

Please bond each part.

I am challenging aging painting.
I use'd 3M-3099AB 3D printer platform sheet. very good.

It is an explanation of how to make it.
http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Watch-Stand/

Printer:

PRN3D for Micro-factory

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

ABS
First, design it.

Fidgeting is something we all do or have done but we seem to have no good ways to deal with it. My version of the fidget cube may be the way to deal with this. All the pats of this cube can be 3d printed and require no extra hardware during assembly. It has a joystick, rotating dials, a spinner, and other great features to suit your fidgeting needs.

Why I Remixed It?
The Fidget Cube by CThig was very close to the original Antsylabs Fidget Cube that was on kickstarter earlier this year. However, it lacked many features that i wanted on it such as (most notably) a joystick. I also wanted to give the user the ability to swap out current features for new ones simply by popping out the old one and replacing it with a different feature. By doing this, you can also allow the input of new features that the user deigned him or herself. This is my version of the Fidget Cube!

Major Changes Include:
-There is now a fully working but simple joystick
-The panels and frame are easily removable so the user can swap out current functions for new ones. This also enables the user to design new features that can fit into the cube's frame as long as the panel is 50mmx50mm.
-The cube is slightly larger to accommodate for more complex functions that require more space inside to work properly.

Minor Changes:
-The cube's parts are separated into different parts so that assembly is easier.
-Added a spinning disc that rotates more freely
-Designed in a way that makes it so the user doesn't need any extra hardware to put the cube together.

To print this model, you should have a bed size of at least 60mmx60mm and a Z- axis build height of 100mm.
My recommended settings for printing:
Part Name: Fidget Cube Frame.stl
Quantity Needed: 1
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Print Settings
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Wall Thickness: 0.4-0.8
Top/Bottom Thickness:0.7
Infill:10-20%
Speed: 50-60mm/s
Build Plate Adhesion: None
Supports: Yes, set to "everywhere" in cura

Part Name: Fidget Disc.stl
Quantity Needed: 1
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Print Settings
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Wall Thickness: 0.4-0.8
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.9
Infill: 5-10%
Speed: 50mm/s
Build Plate Adhesion: Doesn't Matter
Supports: No

Part Name: Rev1 Joystick Backplate.stl
Quantity: 1
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Print Settings
Layer Height: 0.2
Wall Thickness: 0.4
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.7
Infill:10%
Bulid Plate Adhesion: Brim
Supports: No

Part Name: Joystick Ball.stl
Quantity: 1
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Layer Height: 0.1-0.2mm
Wall Thickness:0.4-0.8
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.7
Infill: 0-10%
Build Plate Adhesion: Brim
Supports: No

Part Name(s): Joystick Faceplate.stl, Spinning Disc Faceplate.stl, Thumb Rest Plate.stl, Keychain Faceplate.stl, Fidget Wheels Faceplate.stl, 9x9 Buttons Face Plate.
Quantity: 1 of each
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Layer Height: 0.1-0.2mm
Wall Thickness: 0.4
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.8
Infill: 10-25%
Build Plate Adhesion: Doesn't matter
Part Name: 9X9 Buttons.stl
Quantity: 1
Material: Flexible or PLA. Note: If printed in PLA, buttons will have little or no flex to them.
Layer Height: 0.2-0.25mm
Wall Thickness: 0.4
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.7
Infill: 0-10%

Fidget Wheels Spinners.stl
Quantity: 5
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Layer Height:0.1-0.25
Wall Thickness: 0.4
Infill: 7-10%
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.8
Build Plate Adhesion Type: None

Part Name: Disc Lock.stl
Quantity: 1
Material: PLA, ABS, PET, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Layer Height: 0.25
Wall Thickness: 0.4
Infill: 7-10%
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.8
Build Plate Adhesion: None

Part Name: Joystick Thumbstick
Quantity: 1
Material: PLA, ABS, PETG, PETG, PLA PRO/PLA+
Layer Height: 0.2
Wall Thickness: 0.4
Infill: 10%
Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.7
Build Plate Adhesion Type: None

Some common tools you will need include:
-A hot glue gun and hot glue sticks
-Files
-Sandpaper

For all parts, I used eSUN PLA/PLA+ and it took a total of 14 hours to print but your time may vary due to your settings. Please also note that every printer is different and you may need to adjust your settings accordingly. Post a make if you end up successfully making one too. I have also published an instructable that will fully guide you on how to assemble the Fidget cube and the link is here or you can follow the pictures below if you prefer to do so,
http://www.instructables.com/id/Fully-3D-Printed-Fidget-Cube-Replica/
Remove support material and follow the instructable or pictures below for assembly. You don't need any extra hardware to put this together but you will require some extra tools.
I used both 123D Design and Fusion 360 to design the parts for the fidget cube.

Assembly of the Joystick

For this step you need the following pieces:
-Joystick_Ball.stl (1x)
-Joystick_Thumbstick.stl (1x)
-Joystick_Faceplate.stl (1x)

  • Rev1_Joystick_Backplate.stl (1x)
1. Slide the joystick through the faceplate. 2. Slide the joystick backplate through the holes on the faceplate. File or sand the tabs off until it's flush with the faceplate.

Assembling the 9X9 Buttons

For this step you need the following pieces:
-9X9_Button_Face_Plate.stl (1x)
-9X9_Buttons.stl (1x)

1. File down the holes until the 9x9 buttons fit. 2. Push the 9x9 button into place.

Assembling the Spinning Disc

The pieces you need for this step are:
-Spinning_Disc_Faceplate.stl (1x)
-Disc_Lock.stl (1x)
-Fidget_Disc.stl (1x)

1. Slide the disc lock through the back of the faceplate. 2. Put a small dab of hot glue onto the head of the disc lock. 3. Place the disc onto the disc lock's head and hold firmly until the hot glue is set up.

Assembling the Rotating Discs

Parts you need:
-FidgetWheelsSpinners.stl (5x)
-Fidget_Wheels_Faceplate.stl (1x)

1. Thread a paper clip through each of the wheels. 2. Cut off the excess of the paper clip. 3 Secure each of the ends with hot glue.

Finishing the Cube

The pieces you need:
-All the parts you assembled in previous steps
-KeyChainFacePlate.stl (1x)
-Thumb_Rest_Plate.stl (1x)

1. You should have the same parts as shown above. 2. Snap the 9x9 button assembly into the frame. 3. Snap the keychain faceplate into the frame and put a dab of hot glue in the corner. 4. Snap the spinning disc assembly into the frame. 5. Snap the fidget wheels assembly into the frame. 6. Snap the joystick and remaining faceplates into the frame and you've successfully made a fidget cube!

Donate!

Tip Me on Thingiverse $3 and you will be gifted my very own maker coin. Just message me after tipping and I will send you a file!

http://www.instructables.com/id/Fully-3D-Printed-Fidget-Cube-Replica/
Hope that helps! Happy printing!

description.text:
Building of buying a big sander for little and delicate thing, is too much. So I have decided to remix this and fit it to my sending pad. You can buy the pad in the following link:
http://www.banggood.com/2-Inch-50mm-Hook-and-Loop-Sanding-Pad-14-Inch-Shank-with-60pcs-100-to-2000-Grit-Sand-Paper-Kit-p-1089070.html?p=9R09143243493201512Z

Note:

  1. The sanding paper must be aligned to the PAD. If not, you will get vibrations and it will not work well.
  2. Make sure you bolt all the parts to a table or base because of the vibration.
  3. As any power tools, using this at your own risk, I would not be responsible in case of injury or improper use in any form.

A 5.1 speaker mount system that attaches to a desktop monitor stand's center column. The side speakers mount to the frame using the slide-over-screw slot on the back of the speaker base. The center speaker simply sits on the center platform.

I designed it for my Vivo brand desktop monitor stand, which has a center column diameter of ~36mm.

I've included my schematic and the stl files for the glowing embellishments; these are purely for decoration and can be omitted if desired.

Let me know if you have any questions!

Print Quantity and Assembly Notes

ColumnAttachment: 1 - this prints with 2 ArmPiece's, 1 on each side.

ArmPiece: 6 - I needed 3 for each side, this value will vary with how far out you need the speakers to sit.

ConnectingBracket: 8 - one of these is needed for each ArmPiece and another for the speaker mounting plates on either end of the arms. These brackets are a tight fit, I had to shave a few down a bit. I then used a mallet to nudge them all in to place. They fit in between each of the ArmPiece's and also between the last ArmPiece and a female cutout on the back of the SpeakerPlate's.

CenterPlatform: 1 - this has a cutout in the bottom and should fit snugly over the center column. Use CenterPlatform_noControlPlate if you don't want the lighting control panel piece.

SpeakerPlate: 2 - one right and one left.

Decorations

The decorations on the sides of the speaker plates:
Pipe: 1
PipeConnector_90: 2

The center glowing sphere component consists of:
Sphere: 1
Pipe: 8
PipeConnector_45: 4

The Sphere and Pipe pieces should be printed with a clear filament. I printed the sphere with a single wall count. I used a clear resin, with a small drop of white dye, to coat the sphere and pipes. I'm not sure if the resin made much of a difference on the pipes, but it did add some strength to the sphere. The resin could probably be omitted entirely with thicker walls printed on the sphere, I'm not sure the single wall makes much of a difference anyway.

The sphere pipes will need to be cut slightly in order to avoid having to bow the pipes outward. The goal is for the pipes to fit in to the receptacles on the sphere such that they will sit flat on a level surface. This should allow them to sit in the CenterPlatform without too much work.

Lighting

I used RGB led's, despite only showing blue in the pictures. I have a potentiometer controlling each color which allows for any combination of colors an RGB led can achieve. The schematic for circuit I built to control the led color is included with the files.

The PipeConnector_90 piece has a holster for a 5mm led inside of it. Each of the decorative glowing side pieces has an led in the top and bottom PipeConnector_90.

The sphere has four 5mm led's 1 is fed up through each of the four pipes. They should each sit just barely inside of the sphere, so that the bottom rim of the led sits just inside the sphere itself. I achieved this by estimating how high each led should sit from the top of the pipe and then glued it to the side of the pipe. Then the sphere slid over the led's in order to fit the sphere to the pipes

author: ZerOine

description.text:
This is a version of my cageless bearing, but much easier to assemble. Actually it is not completely cageless since the rollers need to be constrained, but it can be manufactured pretty easily with 45° angled rollers at the end so they can be frictionless contained. Actually it's just a proof of concept. I only used 0.2 tolerance for the mounting aid, the need for additional tolerances remains to be found out, print is currently in progress.

UPDATE: apparently... I should have used more spacing. Inside and outside fit over the rollers in the mounting plate, but don't fit together since apparently the pins are slightly pushed in- or outwards. Very tricky to dial in, since it should be a press fit... please update me if you managed to dial it in.

UPDATE 2: fixed an error of not adding the tolerance to the outer ring. After printing, I measured and corrected the spacing accordingly, so in theory now it should fit (better). Notice that a deviation of 0.1195 in radius resulted in the roller formation to collapse...

UPDATE 3: I noticed if the bearing is loaded, the rollers at the bottom will be pushed away, pushing the rollers above together. So, I guess if the concept works, it should work close to 45° roller angle since then the movement when the bearing is not spinning does not cause the roller constellation to collapse.

For printing, flip 180 degrees. As rollers I used 6x14mm dowel pins. Apparently customizer is not able to load the attached libs... so, doesn't work.

Shortcut functions and other libs curtesy of the OpenSCAD master parkinbot ;)

comments.text: If you complicate the surface of the rollers and add more space between them filling everything with a supersticky oil, it will become a viscous coupling unit.
comments.author: BPKujawa

comments.text: Awsome idea, not sure it works(might be using it wrong), printed one anyway, looks damn cool as a desk "ornament" tho!
comments.author: anderikk

comments.text: Don't the double acting rollers turn against the direction of travel, making this not work? or am I somehow missing the design intention from the pic?
comments.author: exosequitur

comments.text:
I believe there should be one or three levels of rollers to get individual turning of inner and outer ring!
Otherwise they block each other.
comments.author: exosequitur

comments.text: They do rotate counterrotating to the shaft, but I hope it works anyway, why shouldn't it? :)
comments.author: exosequitur

comments.text: No, it will not. Interestingly, if the surfaces are smooth enough (which, sadly, they won't be), the rollers will be able to roll around freely between the inner and outer rings, but you'll still be fighting the full friction if you try to actually try to move one of the rings relative to the other.

title: Mini Floor Stands
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Mini Floor Stands are just that... a fairly large range of small stand with fun / warning / safety messages. They are a print-in-place design with two sign faces plus an arm to lock the stand in place. Easy prints for practical and fun applications... just click on the Files tab to view the range. A blank option is also available that can be edited (add text) or used with an adhesive sticker, piece of card or similar.

A colour change is required as soon as you see the letters starting to form. Just pause your machine, change the filament then re-start and finish your sign. Use whatever colors you want as long as there is adequate contrast between the stand part and the text.

Mini Floor Signs are a great way to communicate a message at home or at work. They are fun little things that, in many instances, have practical value. Use them to good effect!

Please refer to the print settings and information for additional information... and post images of your Mini Floor Stands in use for others to see.

And, if you like this design, check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

2 Shells / 15% infill or more / PLA

Notes:

Easy prints...

Just remove the raft then stand up and lock in place...

Refer to the images provided for additional information.

Sometimes it's the simple and basic tools that you'll find the most useful in your arsenal of 3D printer tool box.

comments.text: I agree.  This tool is not at all anything but a basic beginners tool. And some of the info from march 31 is way off the mark. This tool could be used during a build but fine adjustments should be made with a feeler gauge set.  If you dont have feeler gauges and you have owned a 3d printer for more than a month then you really still are a complete amateur.  Its OK but buy one immediately.  This crap with Prusa using lame ass crutches and sorry amateurish techniques is pathetic. As an experienced builder who has real tools the instructions were infuriating.  I cant stand catering to amateurs rather than teaching them to do thi gs right. You in no way should be building an i3 kit without feeler gauges and a 6" metric calipers.   They should at least make the highly recommended tools to buy.
comments.author: kdpainter

comments.text: Great littel tool, works well.. great to get you very close if not spot on ...Remeber to reset to Z 0 then adjust probe..

comments.text: Great tool, but always remember to set the Live Z Adjust to 0 before running the Calibration, as most likely you are going to raise the PIND and noozle will hit the heatbed then.

comments.text: Good point, however at least in my experience on the MK2S, re-running the Calibration zeroed the Live Z axis anyway - which is what one would expect should happen.

comments.text: I printed this yesterday. It does not provide a perfect setting right away, but gives a much better guideline for initial setting of the PINDA, than the photo in the Prusa manual. I needed to lower the PINDA slightly to avoid the nozzle touching the bed. I improved my Z offset from -0.720 to 0.380 (for PLA) with the aid of this tool. Always run the initial XYZ calibration with a piece of paper on the bed, as mentioned in the manual

description.text:
This is the exact opposite of my "Cube in Sphere" design (Thing #14878), with a twist.  Instead of printing the ball, I designed the open-sided cube to fit around an existing ball that I have had lying around for awhile.
I also just noticed that this design is very similar to Things # 8846 ("3D Sphere in Cube") and #5181 ("Block with Ball")... not to sound anything like Dr. Seuss, of course.  :)
It took me 5 prints to accomplish this, mostly because I'm a single father and had 2 children running around the house while printing the first 4.  I've gotten used to not monitoring my prints, and failed to check on the first 4 prints before it was too late to "drop the ball".
Have you ever seen a cube roll before?  My print does just that... and my 7-year-old boy is fascinated by it.
Try it!

WHAT YOU NEED:
1) An old can of spray paint, or any other aerosol can with a shaker ball.
2) A bon-fire.
3) Safety glasses, or 43 acres of land so you can get away from the bon-fire.
4) A special permit from the EPA, BATF, FBI, CIA, NSA, and local authorities (including your wife) that allows you to burn aerosol cans in an open fire (or 43 acres of land).
5) The ability and/or luck to find the shaker ball (much like a marble, only larger) after the can explodes and sends things flying everywhere.
6) A Thing-O-Matic with firmware that allows you to pause the print and jog the build surface (i.e. Thing #15380 by "jetty", which is one of the best upgrades I have on my Thing-O-Matic, other than LED lighting).
HOW TO DO IT:
1) The shaker ball that I used measured 25.25mm during several measurements with digital calipers.  I was actually amazed by the consistent measurements of this sphere, and wondered why a shaker ball needs to be so accurate.  Any non-uniform rock of similar size would do the trick, really.
Anyhow, you will need to scale my .STL file up or down, depending on the size of sphere you have available to you.  For instance, my son has a marble that he would like me to do the same thing with.  I got measurements of 16.28mm, 16.22mm, 16.20mm, and 16.18mm, depending where I measured his marble (which I found odd, compared to the accuracy of my shaker ball).  The average measurement (all measurements added together, then divided by 4... for anyone who didn't pass 3rd grade) is 16.22mm.
Then calculate the percentage of scale adjustment needed on my .STL file, in order to fit your sphere... and enter that result into the "scale" dialogue of Replicator-G.  
Note that my original CAD design was with a cube of 26mm outside and 19mm inside dimensions.  These dimensions, after printing, came out to be 26.32mm outside and 18.45mm inside.
2) My design at 100% scale took about 38 minutes to print with a raft and no support.  Do not add full support, or you won't be able to get the ball in.  That was my first print mistake.  I added exterior support on the 2nd print, but it did nothing.  So you do not need support at all.  Yes, the top horizontal sections will have a bit of sag on the 1st layer or 2.  But it will all work just fine... or should.  Mine did.  Just make sure to pause your print at the right time, then jog your build platform forward to carefully drop the sphere inside.  Then resume the print, and everything should go just fine.  (This is why you need firmware such as "jetty's" Thing #15380, or one of his newer versions.)
3) You need to monitor this print fairly closely, because it's important that you pause the print at the top of the 4 vertical sections... just before your machine starts printing the horizontal bars.
4) Enjoy the challenge.  It's not that difficult... monitoring your print in order to pause it at the right time is the key.

Full MS link: http://biorxiv.org/content/early/2016/12/13/093633
Open-Labware link: https://open-labware.net/projects/openspritzer/

Openspritzer: an open hardware pressure ejection system for reliably delivering picolitre volumes.

Chris J Forman, Hayley Tomes, Buchule Mbobo, Tom Baden, Joseph V Raimondo

The ability to reliably and precisely deliver picolitre volumes is an important component of biological research. Here we describe a high-performance, low-cost, open hardware pressure ejection system (Openspritzer), which can be constructed from off the shelf components. When connected to a standard micro-pipette via suitable pneumatic tubing, the device is capable of delivering minute doses of reagents to a wide range of biological and chemical systems. In this work, we characterise the performance of the device and compare it to a popular commercial system using two-photon fluorescence microscopy. We found that Openspritzer provides the same level of control over delivered reagent dose as the commercial system. Next, we demonstrate the utility of Openspritzer in a series of standard neurobiological applications. First, we used Openspritzer to deliver precise amounts of the neurotransmitters glutamate and GABA to hippocampal neurons to elicit time- and dose-precise excitatory and inhibitory responses, respectively. Second, we used Openspritzer to deliver infectious viral and bacterial agents to living tissue. Viral transfection of hippocampal interneurons with channelrhodopsin allowed for the optogenetic manipulation of hippocampal circuitry with light. Finally, we successfully used Openspritzer to infect organotypic hippocampal slice cultures with fluorescent Mycobacterium bovis bacilli. We anticipate that due to its high performance and low cost Openspritzer will be of interest to a broad range of researchers working in the life and physical sciences.

title: Two Wu Tang inductrix tiny whoop frames

description.text:
This is a Wu Tang Frame that fits Blade inductrix and tiny whoop parts. I have always wanted to do something like this and now I have.

It has been a week since I first got my first 3d printer Monoprice Select Mini. I am a complete noob but learned at in a short amount of time.

I used the Wu-Tang Ashtray by gungn1r to get the Wu Tang Logo and then I used the the motor mount and FC mount from the Inductrix / TinyWhoop - Easy to print, plug-and-play frame replacement by PeterProvost.

The software I found easiest to edit a model is Tinkercad online.

There are two versions of this frame available. Frame 3 is smaller than Frame4. Frame3 has part of the props exposed and 3 grams.I designed v4 to have better prop protection but it is 6 grams. Update as of 12/24/16 - Will need to trim the fat off the larger frame. Want to get it at least 5 grams.

I had longer screws which holds the fc from the bottom and comes up to hold the cam mount. The battery is being held on by rubberband hooked on the top of the screw on each side.

Would love to see pics of others building this. I added motor guard to protect motor wires from getting damaged. The STL file only has one. You will need to print four of that file.Not sure if needed but I used eyeglass frame tightner to prevent the motor from moving up or you can use an o ring.You can see it on the picture showing the bottom.

You can get all parts for this at www.tinywhoop.com
I recommend Insane motors, Beebrain flight controller and LiHV batteries.
Enjoy :)

title: Micrometer Stand for Mitutoyo 293 Series, etc.

description.text:
A bench mounted micrometer stand for the Mitutoyo 293 Series micrometers. Will probably hold other models also.

You will need a 1/4"-20tpi by 3/4" socket head cap screw (or a hex head screw will work too), and a 1/4"-20 jam nut (a standard nut won't fit). Drop the nut into the slot in the bottom of the stand and thread the screw into it. Mount the stand to a bench using two #4 wood screws through the mounting ears.

The 1/4" screw, when tightened, pushes the vertical tab against the frame of the micrometer to hold it in place.

author: Grogo666

description.text:
This is a simple two colour Christmas Tree card that I designed in Solidworks.

TLDR: Follow the screenshots attached to see how to dual extrude this using ReplicatorG.

It also serves as a good example of a simple dual extrusion.
I've uploaded some screenshots and detailed the main steps to create your first dual extrusion using the Flashforge Creator PRO with the ReplicatorG slicing software.

I found that the out-of-the-box ReplicatorG instructions with the Flashforge Creator PRO for dual extrusion quite confusing, so in this page, I've summarised the steps that I use.
Since the ReplicatorG software is not very user friendly, there is quite a bit of fiddling around to get the two colours of the dual extrusion to match up correctly.

There are much better software products available which will allow for a much easier user interface for dual extruding (e.g FlashPrint). However, I find that ReplicatorG has the best print settings for the Flashforge Creator PRO 2016.

Steps to dual extrude using ReplicatorG:

  1. After opening ReplicatorG, go to GCode > Merge .stl for DualExtrusion.
  2. Browse the two .stl files that you want to dual extrude. One .stl file will be loaded for the left extruder and the other .stl will be loaded for the right extruder. Choose the left / right extruder depending on what colours you have loaded into your printer.
    After this, browse in the "Save As" box and then name your file something useful. I used "ChristmasCard.gcode".
    MAKE SURE YOU ADD .gcode TO THE END OF THE FILE NAME.
    Then click "Merge".
  3. Two pop ups will open, these are the print settings for the left and right extruder. If you are using two different materials then these settings could be different. Otherwise, they should be the same.
    Choose your print settings and then click "Generate Gcode" for both the left and right extruders.
  4. Wait for the files to be generated. There will be 3 files generated in total. These are:
    • .gcode for left extruder
    • .gcode for right extruder
    • .gcode for the merged file
  5. After generating the .gcode files, upload the file to your printer as you would with any other print from this window. Your printer should automatically switch between the left and right extruder as defined by the two original .stl files.

description.text:
German bellow

WeSaCom APT-06 Receiver holder
The WeSaCom APT-06 weather receiver from WRAASE Electronic GmbH is intended to receive the NOAA weather satellite and its APT signal. Using the "WXtoImage" software, the signal can be decoded and then the weather data can be used for own weather forecasts.

This bracket is designed for table mounting or rack mounting. It is as small as possible, with maximum stability. The rubber feet located underneath the unit do not have to be dismantled. You can also buy the finished bracket here http://www.drohnenshop-berlin.de/WeSaCom-APT-06-Receiver-holder

To find out more about our weather project in combination with drones, please visit: http://www.berlinerardrone.de/tag/noaa/

WeSaCom APT-06 Empfänger Halterung
Der WeSaCom APT-06 Wettersatelliten Empfänger der Firma WRAASE Electronic GmbH ist zum empfang der NOAA Wettersatelliten und dessen APT Signal gedacht. Mit Hilfe der Software "WXtoImage" kann das Signal Dekodiert werden und im Anschluss die Wetterdaten für eigene Wetter Vorhersagen verwendet werden.

Diese Halterung ist für eine unter Tisch Montage oder für einen Regal Einbau gedacht. Sie ist so klein wie möglich, bei höchster Stabilität. Die Unter dem Gerät befindlichen Gummi Füße müssen nicht Demontiert werden. Sie können die Fertige Halterung auch hier Kaufen http://www.drohnenshop-berlin.de/WeSaCom-APT-06-Empfaenger-Halterung

Mehr über unser Wetter Projekt in Kombination mit Drohnen, finden sie unter http://www.berlinerardrone.de/tag/noaa/

Drone laboratory

Weather data is one of the most important criteria for economic and private project planning worldwide. The saving of costs, protection against avoidable damage and the tactically most favorable planning for the most efficient use of the given circumstances can be carried out promptly and very reliably on the basis of correct data evaluation

In today's world, the desired data, usually current satellite imagery and forecasts by experienced experts, can be easily retrieved in the digital world. If, however, little or even no telephone reception is available, as is still the case in remote or strongly isolated areas, an alternative must be offered. Particularly in the case of planned TV and film productions or in the case of multicopter flights and the like, the corresponding basic information must already be obtained beforehand.

We have set ourselves the goal of creating a mobile system for the rental, which can be transported in the HPRC case series. At the present time, we are intensively testing the retrieval of specific data from the NOAA satellites (National Ocean and Atmospheres Administration), which orbit around the earth at an altitude of roughly 800 kilometers and provide new images free of charge. By radio signal, 137 MHz images are sent to the earth, which are accessible to anyone with the right decoding technology. The required software builds up the image material in stages according to the reception strength and automatically corrects loading errors. The available weather images include, among other things, important information, such as cloud formation and temperature conditions within the selected area.

An example of the use would be the preparation for the flight with an aircraft, for example a drone or a quadrocopter, which is equipped with a camera system. Only with the help of a windmometer and several weather pictures, which are transmitted every few hours by the satellites, one can calculate the next suitable time for flying.

To find out more about our weather project in combination with drones, please visit: http://www.berlinerardrone.de/tag/noaa/

Drohnen Labor

Wetterdaten sind weltweit eine der wichtigsten Kriterien für wirtschaftliche und private Projektplanungen. Die Einsparung von Kosten, Absicherung gegen vermeidbare Schäden und die taktisch günstigste Planung für die effizienteste Nutzung der gegebenen Umstände, können anhand richtiger Datenauswertung zeitnah und sehr zuverlässig erfolgen

In der heutigen Zeit kann man die gewünschten Daten, im Regelfall aktuelle Satellitenbilder und Prognosen von erfahrenen Fachleuten, problemlos in der digitalen Welt abrufen. Steht jedoch nur wenig oder sogar gar kein Telefonempfang zur Verfügung, wie es in weit abgelegenen oder stark isolierten Gebieten auch heute noch der Fall ist, muss eine Alternative geboten werden. Gerade bei geplanten TV- und Filmproduktionen oder bei Multicopter Flügen und ähnlichem, müssen vorab schon die entsprechenden Basisinformationen eingeholt werden können.

Wir haben es uns zum Ziel gesetzt, ein mobiles System für die Vermietung zu schaffen, das sich in der HPRC Koffer Serie transportieren lässt. Zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt testen wir intensiv den Abruf spezifischer Datenmengen von den NOAA Satelliten (Nationale Ozean und Atmosphären Administration), welche in etwa 800 Kilometern Höhe die Erde umkreisen und kontinuierlich neues Bildmaterial kostenlos zur Verfügung stellen. Per Funksignal werden auf 137 MHz Bilder zur Erde geschickt, die uneingeschränkt für jeden zugänlich sind, der über die passende Entschlüsselungstechnik verfügt. Die benötigte Software baut das Bildmaterial etappenweise je nach Empfangsstärke auf und korrigiert Ladefehler automatisch. Die so erhältlichen Wetterbilder beinhalten unter anderem wichtige Informationen, wie Wolkenaufbau und Temperaturverhältnisse innerhalb des gewählten Gebietes.

Ein Beispiel für die Nutzung wäre die Vorbereitung für den Flug mit einem Fluggerät, zum Beispiel einer Drohne oder einem Quadrocopter, welches mit einem Kamerasystem ausgestattet ist. Nur mit Hilfe eines Windmessers und mehrer Wetterbilder, die alle paar Stunden von den Satelliten übertragen werden, kann man den nächst passenden Zeitpunkt zum Fliegen errechnen.

Mehr über unser Wetter Projekt in Kombination mit Drohnen, finden sie unter http://www.berlinerardrone.de/tag/noaa/

title: Boxer at Rest
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Boxer at Rest

A printable model of Boxer at Rest, a.k.a. Terme Boxer or Boxer of the Quirinal. This is a fantastic example of Greek, bronze statues that have lived on to modern times. The statue now resides at a museum in Rome.

Attribution

I did not create or capture this model myself, I cleaned up this 123d Catch model and made it printable.

The Models

There is one larger and one smaller version of each: With segments of the floor (for added stability and adhesion) and without. You may need a brim for the smaller versions, depending on your printer.

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

You can get away with other resolutions (especially larger resolutions for the bigger models) and infill percentages. I wouldn't go above 15 or 20% for the infill percentage, because it would become extremely time consuming — especially for the larger models.

Supports work well with an overhang threshold of 40°

Remove the Supports

Remove the supports rather carefully, especially around the hands. Everywhere else should be pretty sturdy.

This is a cleaned up version of this 123d Catch model.

I removed some extraneous material in MeshMixer before rotating it so that it would print correctly and cutting it at the base (a few times) to provide a flat, printable area. This cutting is how the two variations of the model (with floor and without) came about. In order to isolate the pedestal, I had to cut away some small part of it at the bottom — but it's not too much that it comes out looking odd or is something to be worried about.

description.text:
Action camera helmet side holder

I made this holder to be connected directly on helmet by 3M VHB tape or zip tie. However zip ties requires to makes holes into helmet, which is not recommended way (keep on mind that any modification of your helmet means void of its warranty and have negative impact on helmets protection ability!).

Holder consists of 2 parts so it can be folded when it is not used. Camera is connected over 1/4 stativ screw. Theoretically there can be connected any of FDR Sony action cams, but personally I tested only FDR-X3000 and FDR-X1000.

Additional parts:

  • Screw ISO4017 - M5x40
  • Nut ISO4032 - M5
  • 1/4 stativ screw (e.g GITZO D116.138)

Changelog:

  • 7.1.2017

    After day on snow in mountains I found that stativ screw wrapped by ice made impossible to remove camera from helmet till ice is melt. Therefore I modified screw head. Groves on the side of head was replaced by smooth surface to prevent from locking by ice.

  • 8.12.2016

    Created first model of holder. Model was successfully tested at home.

remixed_from.author: WHITECOAT
remixed_from.title: Homebrew Blade Server Case - Fully printable (Mini-ITX)

title: Homebrew Blade Server - Assorted 2.5" HDD mounts

description.text:
This is a set of 2.5" HDD mounts intended for use in my Homebrew Blade Server (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:184301).
All STL's are manifold and have been tested in Slicer.

• Single 2.5" HDD Quick release mount - Uses a latch to hold the HDD to the blade so that it can be easily removed if needed. You can put one on both top and bottom of the blade for a total of 2 HDD's. (It does work fairly well, but its a little loose, I don't consider it finished. I'm open to suggestions on how to improve it)
  • Double 2.5" HDD bay - Going for maximum capacity, you can put two of these bays side by side on the back of a blade for a total of 4 HDD's. At todays HDD capacities that would be up to 8TB).

• 3.5" HDD mount - It should be possible to do a 3.5" HDD mount as well, for my current purposes I haven't done this as only two drives would fit in the same space, which with any redundancy would limit you to 4TB. Where as with 4x 2." HDD's I can get 6TB with one redundant HDD in the same space.
  • RAID Storage Blade - If you were to use the entire width of a blade you could stack in a fair few drives vertically. (I might take that on as a future project if no one beats me to it).

There is an assembled image in the sketch-up file for each combination so that you can see how the pieces go together.  Along with the included pictures I hope it is fairly obvious how it works, but... drop me a line if anything needs clarification.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed all parts in orange PLA, with two perimeters.

description.text:
This thing allows to mount a Logitech C270 USB camera to your Hephestos 2's Y-carriage, to have it move with the bed during printing and allow a view of the ongoing print undisturbed by motion. Naturally I use this with OctoPrint ;)

This thing mounts into two existing M4 holes on the front of the Hephestos 2's Y-carriage. The position of camera is designed such that the lens is located on the center line of the bed. The camera's front is located just outside the movement area of the print head and thus should not cause any problems.

Note: I so far have not discovered any artifacts in my prints caused by the added weight in 4 months of printing with this setup, but YMMV. Also, for high prints the model might run out of the visible angle - I'm still looking into somehow mounting a wide angle attachment to the camera's lens or maybe mount it vertically to compensate for that. If you are concerned about any of these downsides, this might not be the best solution for you.

In order to build this you'll need to print:

  • 1 x cameramount_bracket_left.stl
  • 1 x cameramount_bracket_right.stl (with support from platform)
  • 1 x cameramount_arm_c270.stl (with support for the two hinge components)

Or just:

  • 1 x cameramount_plate.stl (with support as above, should fit on your Hephestos 2's bed)

Additionally you'll need:

  • 2 x M4x10mm screws (e.g. DIN 912)
  • 2 x M3x16mm screws (e.g. DIN 912)
  • 1 x M3x30mm screw (e.g. DIN 912)
  • 3 x M3 hex nut (e.g. DIN 934)

If you need to make any adjustments (e.g. to support another camera model), you can find the Fusion360 files here.

Printer:

Hephestos 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The right bracket and the camera arm need to be printed with support. The left bracket can be printed without.

I printed all parts in orange PLA, with two perimeters.

Exploded view

See the exploded view for assembly instructions. Attempt at a textual description follows ;)

  • Unmount the print bed assembly of your Hephestos 2 from the Y carriage. In the front corners of the carriage/bed holder there are two M4 tapped screw holes, unused. Using the two M4x10mm screws, mount the left and right bracket into the left and right of these holes respectively. The bracket halves should wrap around the front of the carriage and come together in the front center. Make sure the right bracket wraps over the lip of the carriage with the included hook.
  • Using the two M3x16mm screws and M3 nuts, mount the camera arm on the center joint and secure the joint.
  • Detach the stock clip from the Logitech C270 web cam. You only have to remove the hinge, it's a firmly reversible process.
  • Using the M3x30mm screw and another M3 nut, mount the camera to the arm.
  • Make sure the cord of the camera can't catch on the bed in any way. I used some spiral wire tubing I had on hand to force it into a safe bend and secured the other end onto the front frame of the printer with some velcro.
